facts.text: Sambhu Charan Das and Sannyashi Charan Das owned 2 bighas and 18 cottahs of land with a construction thereon in Salkiah, District Howrah.

anchor.surface_text: One Sambhu Charan Das and Sannyashi Charan Das owned 2 bighas and 18 companytahs of land with a companystruction standing thereon, situated in Salkiah, District Howrah.

facts.text: Mortgagors mortgaged the property by conditional sale deed dated June 2, 1933 to secure Rs. 2,750 advanced by Panchu Gopal Srimani through his guardian Prabhavati Dassi.

anchor.surface_text: By a deed of mortgage by companyditional sale dated June 2, 1933 the said owners mortgaged the said property to secure repayment of Rs. 2,750 advanced to them by Panchu Gopal Srimani, then a minor through his mother, Prabhavati Dassi as his certificated guardian.

facts.text: Mortgage due date was April 14, 1935; if not repaid, considered absolute sale and mortgagee entitled to possession.

anchor.surface_text: The said mortgage, inter alia, provided that if the mortgage amount was number repaid by the due date i.e., April 14, 1935 the mortgage would be companysidered as a deed of absolute sale and the mortgagee would be entitled to take possession of the property.

facts.text: Mortgagors assigned their rights in the property to Satchindananda Hazra on June 18, 1934.

anchor.surface_text: On June 18, 1934 the mortgagors assigned their right, title and interest in the said property to one Satchindananda Hazra.

facts.text: Mortgagee filed suit on July 17, 1945 for enforcement, impleading mortgagors and Hazra, praying for Rs. 5,426/10/6 and foreclosure on default.

anchor.surface_text: As the said mortgagors or the said Hazra failed to pay the said mortgage amount on the due date, the mortgagee filed a suit on July 17, 1945 for enforcement of his rights impleading the two mortgagors and the said Hazra as defendants. In that plaint the mortgagee prayed for a decree for Rs. 5,426/10/6, being the amount then due under the said mortgage and for fixing the time for. payment of the said amount.

facts.text: Trial Court passed preliminary decree on December 23, 1946 for Rs. 5,426/10/6, payment within six months, else final decree for sale.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court rejected these companytentions and passed a pre- liminary decree on December 23, 1946. The said decree, inter alia, provided that the mortgage amount due was Rs. 5,426/10/6 and that if the said amount together with companyts of the suit was number paid by the defendants within six months from the date of the decree the plaintiff would be at liberty to apply for a final decree.

facts.text: Hazra filed appeal against preliminary decree in Calcutta High Court, dismissed on March 22, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Against the said preliminary decree the said Hazra filed an appeal in the High Court at Calcutta raising two companytentions, ... The High Court negatived these companytentions and by its judgment and decree dated March 22, 1951 dismissed the said appeal

facts.text: Respondent obtained money decree against Hazra, levied attachment on mortgaged property, sold on June 23, 1950, respondent auction purchaser of 1 bigha 2 cottahs, confirmed February 15, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: While the said appeal was pending the respondent obtained a money decree against the said Hazra and companymenced execution proceedings against him. An attachment was levied on the said mortgaged property and thereafter on June 23, 1950 the right, title and interest of the said Hazra was put up for sale. The respondent was the auction purchaser and the companyrt companyfirmed the said sale by an order dated February l5,1951. The said auction sale was in respectof 1 bigha and 2 companytahs out of the said mortgagee property.

facts.text: Respondent claims possession given on May 3, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: According to the respondent he was given possession of the said property on May 3, 1951.

facts.text: Panchu Gopal Srimani applied for final decree on March 1, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: On March 1, 1954, the said mortgagee, Panchu Gopal Srimani, applied for a final decree in the said suit.

facts.text: Mortgagee assigned rights to appellants on May 31, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Pending this application, he assigned his right in the said decree in favour of the appellants on May 31, 1954.

facts.text: Appellants applied for substitution on July 1, 1954, ordered on January 5, 1955 after notice.

anchor.surface_text: On July 1, 1954 the appellants applied to the Trial Court for being substituted in place of the said Panchu Shrimani. The Trial Court directed numberices to be issued on the defendants, that is, the said two mortgagors and the said Hazra and they having raised numberobjection the companyrt by an order dated January 5, 1955 ordered substitution and then passed a final decree.

facts.text: Trial Court passed final foreclosure decree after substitution.

anchor.surface_text: The said decree, after reciting that the said decretal amount was number paid within the time appointed by the defendants or any other person entitled to redeem the said mortgage, provided as follows- And it is hereby ordered and declared that the defendant and all persons claiming through or under him are absolutely debarred and foreclosed of and from all rights of -redemption of and in the property in the aforesaid preliminary decree mentioned and that the defendant shall deliver to the plaintiff quiet and peaceful possession of the said mortgaged property.

facts.text: Appellants obtained possession on April 19, 1955 application.

anchor.surface_text: On April 19, 1955 the appellants applied for and obtained possession of the said mortgaged property.

facts.text: Respondent filed O.21 r.100 application on May 25, 1955, rejected September 27, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: According to the respondent, however he learnt about the possession of the said mortgaged property having been delivered to the appellants for the first time on May 25, 1955 and thereupon filed an application under O. 21 r. 100 of the Code for restoration of possession to him. On September 27, 1955 the Trial Court rejected that application.

facts.text: Respondent filed revision on January 3, 1956 against O21 r100 dismissal, discharged May 12, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then filed on January 3, 1956 a Revision Application against the said dismissal. ... The High Court also by its order dated May 12, 1961 discharged Civil Rule No. 2 of 1956 issued in the revision application

facts.text: Respondent filed appeal No. 285 of 1956 on August 23, 1955 against final decree.

anchor.surface_text: On August 23, 1955 the respondent filed a second application under section 151 of the Code for setting aside the said final decree. On the same day he also filed an appeal in the High Court being Appeal No. 285 of 1956 against the said final decree

facts.text: Calcutta High Court set aside final decree on May 12, 1961 in Appeal No. 285/1956, remanded to trial court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No. 285 of 1956 came on for hearing on May 12, 1961 before a Division Bench of the High Court. The High Court set aside the final decree observing It is companymon case that the preliminary decree was for sale. ... We should in the result set aside the final mortgage decree and allow the appeal by remitting the matter back to the Court below to be dealt with in accordance with law.

facts.text: Supreme Court Civil Appeal No. 707 of 1964 from High Court judgment dated November 12, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION. Civil Appeal No. 707 of 1964. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated November 12, 1961, of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Original decree No. 285 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, these decisions cannot help Mr. Chatterjee as the position here is number the same as in those two decisions. The, High Court has given its judgment and in pursuance thereof passed a decree setting aside the said final decree. If the High Court had held that the respondent in the circumstances of the case had numberright to maintain his appeal, the final decree would have become a companycluded decree and his right of redemption, if any, would have been totally extinguished.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished Sardar Syedna and Jethanand cases as here High Court set aside final decree and decided locus standi and right to participate/redeem finally, not mere interlocutory remand.

holdings.text: A purchaser pendente lite of equity of redemption has locus standi to file an appeal against the final decree and challenge it.

holdings.text: The Trial Court had jurisdiction under sections 151 and 152 CPC to pass a final foreclosure decree notwithstanding the preliminary decree being for sale due to accidental slip.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inherent power to correct clerical mistakes or accidental slips in judgments/decrees even after signing; suit was for foreclosure, plaint prayers and judgment tenor confirm intention; distinguished cases on variation.

holdings.text: The Trial Court was competent to correct the preliminary decree under O.34 r.4 CPC (for sale) to foreclosure via s.151/152 CPC as it was an accidental slip overlooking the suit nature.

anchor.surface_text: Now, it is well-settled that there is an inherent power in the companyrt which passed the judgment to companyrect a clerical mistake or ,an error arising from an accidental slip or omission and to vary its judgment so as to give effect to its meaning and intention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Supported by precedents like Janakirama Iyer and Mellor v. Swira; O.20 r.3 does not bar s.152 corrections; trial court order noted oversight; no third party rights intervened validly.

holdings.text: The respondent, as execution purchaser pendente lite of part equity of redemption, is not entitled to redeem the mortgage as he is bound by lis pendens under s.52 TPA and the result of the litigation including the valid final foreclosure decree.

precedents.case_name: M/s Jethanand Sons v State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: order of remand directing Trial Court to frame fresh issues and try de novo is not a judgment, decree or final order
precedents.cited_holding: the order of remand was not a judgment, decree or final order as it did not amount to a final decision relating to the rights of the parties in dispute

anchor.surface_text: Every court, said Bowen L. J. in Mellor v. Swira 1 has inherent power over its own records so long as those records are within its power and that it can set right any mistake in them.

precedents.cited_proposition: every court has inherent power over its own records to set right any mistake in them
precedents.cited_holding: Every court... has inherent power over its own records so long as those records are within its power and that it can set right any mistake in them

anchor.surface_text: In Janakirama Iyer v. Nilakanta Iyer 2 the decree as drawn up in the High Court had used the words mesne profits instead of net profits.

precedents.cited_proposition: decretal order drawn up through mistake could be corrected under sections 151 and 152 even after certificate granted and appeals admitted
precedents.cited_holding: the decretal order drawn up in the High Court through mistake could be corrected under sections 151 and 152 of the Code even after the High Court had granted certificate and appeals were admitted in this Court

anchor.surface_text: In Barhamdeo Singh v. Harnam Singh 1 though only one of the defendants appeared and contested the suit the order made was that the suit be decreed with costs.

precedents.cited_proposition: decree can be altered if contrary to intention of court gathered from judgment as a whole
precedents.cited_holding: the order made was that the suit be decreed with costs. This was allowed to be altered on the ground that it was contrary to the intention of the court, that such an intention had to be gathered from the judgment as a whole

precedents.cited_proposition: application to correct error may be too late where rights of third parties have intervened based on existence of decree and ignorance of error
precedents.cited_holding: there may possibly be cases in which an application to correct an error of this description would be too late. anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, these decisions cannot help Mr. Chatterjee as the position here is number the same as in those two decisions. The, High Court has given its judgment and in pursuance thereof passed a decree setting aside the said final decree. If the High Court had held that the respondent in the circumstances of the case had numberright to maintain his appeal, the final decree would have become a companycluded decree and his right of redemption, if any, would have been totally extinguished.

In our view, both the contentions raised by the respondent in this behalf must be rejected. What then is the position of the respondent once it is held that the final decree for foreclosure was validly passed by the Trial Court ?
